ud3.3:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud3.3:1.3: Now at that time around five hundred mendicants headed by Yasoja arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
ud3.3:1.4: At that, those visiting mendicants, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.
ud3.3:2.1: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
ud3.3:2.2: “Ānanda, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
ud3.3:2.3: “Sir, those five hundred mendicants headed by Yasoja have arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
ud3.3:2.4: It’s those visiting mendicants who, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.”
ud3.3:2.5: “Well then, Ānanda, in my name tell those mendicants that
ud3.3:3.1: “Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied. He went to those mendicants and said,
ud3.3:3.3: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them,
ud3.3:4.1: “Mendicants, what’s with that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
ud3.3:4.2: When he said this, Venerable Yasoja said to the Buddha,
ud3.3:4.3: “Sir, these five hundred mendicants headed by Yasoja have arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
ud3.3:4.4: It’s these visiting mendicants who, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.”
ud3.3:4.5: “Go away, mendicants, I dismiss you. You are not to stay in my presence.”
ud3.3:5.1: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. They set their lodgings in order and left, taking their bowls and robes.
ud3.3:5.2: Traveling stage by stage in the land of the Vajjīs, they arrived at the Vaggumudā River. They built leaf huts near the riverbank and there they entered the rainy season.
ud3.3:6.1: Then Venerable Yasoja, having entered the rainy season, addressed the mendicants:
ud3.3:6.2: “Out of compassion, reverends, the Buddha dismissed us, wanting what’s best for us.
ud3.3:6.3: Let us live in such a way that the Buddha would be pleased with us.”
ud3.3:6.5: Then those mendicants, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, all realized the three knowledges in that same rainy season.
ud3.3:7.1: When the Buddha had stayed in Sāvatthī as long as he wished, he set out for Vesālī.
ud3.3:7.2: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Vesālī,
ud3.3:7.3: where he stayed in the hall with the peaked roof.
ud3.3:8.1: Then, having focused on comprehending the minds of the mendicants staying near the Vaggumudā River, the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
ud3.3:8.2: “A light, it appears to me, has arisen in this quarter, Ānanda; a brightness has arisen.”
